content:
It is a shame the rest of the film is so discordant

THE END credits of “Vox Lux” roll after only ten minutes. A teenager has opened fire on a classroom of his fellow students before turning the gun on himself, so they mark an abrupt ending for many characters in the film. It is a startling formal trick, signalling to the viewer that they are watching something bold and unusual. In only his second feature, Brady Corbet, the director, is clearly unafraid to push audiences out of their comfort zone. 

The narrative follows Celeste (Raffey Cassidy), the only survivor of the shooting, who, while recovering in hospital, channels her grief into writing a song she later performs at a televised vigil for the victims. The song is complex and stirring—it was written in reality by Sia, a pop star who also served as an executive producer—and, in the story, footage of it goes viral. Celeste quickly acquires a manager (Jude Law) and books a European tour, where, loosely chaperoned by her older sister (Stacy Martin), she loses what little innocence she has left. 

Seventeen years later, and Celeste (now played by Natalie Portman) is a pop star on the verge of a comeback—or, as she insists on calling it, “a rebirth”—after a series of scandals. On the day of her hometown show, meant to kick off the tour, an unnamed group of terrorists commits a mass atrocity on a European beach, wearing masks of Celeste’s face. The meaning of their provocation is unknown, but the reminder of her own trauma sends Celeste into a downwards spiral on one of the most important days of her career.

Although she only appears 45 minutes into the film, it is impossible to imagine “Vox Lux” succeeding at all without Ms Portman’s outlandish portrayal. Her Celeste is difficult to take seriously at first: having grown up in the spotlight, she appears to have ceded her real self to her public image. She assumes a series of postures that leave her unable to meaningfully engage with her daughter, sister or manager, the only constants in her life. She has an exaggerated Staten Island accent that she did not have as a teenager, and stomps from one room to the next. She makes provocative statements to the press (“I’m the new faith”) without reason or explanation, and when asked to explain herself, aggressively changes the subject. Celeste rages against everyone—her family, her colleagues, the press and the world—because she is traumatised, both by the shooting and the appropriation of her grief. 

It’s a go-for-broke performance by Ms Portman, and she redeems a poor script. Mr Corbet uses a wide variety of gimmicks to mask what is at heart a familiar story of an artist corrupted by show business (see also “A Star Is Born” and “All About Eve”). Ms Cassidy, who portrays young Celeste, is also cast as her daughter Albertine in the present day: it is a conspicuous choice meant to indicate the depth of Celeste’s narcissism, but the point could have been better made through characterisation or strong dialogue. Similar shortcuts exist throughout the film, whether in Willem Dafoe’s dreadful omniscient narration (“Celeste’s loss of innocence curiously mirrored that of the nation,” he says at one point) or the pretentious title cards that precede each act of the film, such as “Genesis” and “Re-Genesis”. These formal flourishes raise expectations that the film, despite its best efforts, never quite meets. 

They at least ensure that the viewer will never be bored, for there is always something to try to figure out. Indeed, long after the end, viewers will wonder what Mr Corbet’s point is. His criticisms are sprayed far and wide; “Vox Lux” links school shootings and global terrorism to celebrity culture without drawing a meaningful connection between the subjects. It exists somewhere between absurdist comedy and overwrought melodrama. Perhaps that is the point, and the film is simply a dismal, jarring portrait of the world today.

Now, you might wonder from where you can get the motivation to overcome your fear of failure or comeback after you fail in your pursuit of passion.

How could there be such  failure within and such brilliant success outside?
怎么会有这种外部是辉煌成就而内心是阴暗的失败？

eg2: The rate of population increase has been ratcheting .

Sometimes you serve upward to those in authority, and sometimes you serve  to those in need.
有时你向上服侍那些有权势的人，有时你向下帮助那些有需要的人。
We know the water moves downwards when its left to itself as in rain, but you see if it moves downward on the right that would leave a gap , vacuum a hole in the pipe .
我们知道水都是往下运动的，就好比如同下雨一样，但是你会发现如果在右边的水也向下运动,就会产生一个空隙，在吸管里会有一段真空部分。
